ratings.comment: I would rather be hit by a bus then sit through another minute of his class. Proof based linear algebra in which we didn't learn what we were supposed to. The university overturned his grades sine he failed most of the class.

Sean's an awesome teacher. The best math teacher I've ever had. Extremely patient and charismatic in explaining topics. I would highly recommend this class if you seriously enjoyed linear Algebra. The material covered is similar in spirit, although much more interesting.

Pros: He explains material very well. His lectures are helpful. His tests asked fair questions. He is the teacher you want for an upper-level math class. You will learn a lot.  Cons: He gives a lot of homework. His grading policy is tough. He refused to discuss how the class would be curved, if at all. You'll have to put in a good amount of work.

Delivery of the material is incredibly well thought out. Starts out building up theory for things you're pretty comfortable with, then he shows how those ideas work in increasing levels of abstraction. Homeworks and lectures are very thought provoking. Whole structure of the course forces you to ask why and challenges your assumptions. Great class

I really liked his class and teaching style. He gives plenty of time in lecture for you to process the information and ask questions. He always answered all questions really well and encouraged us to think for ourselves. Homework was vital and extremely helpful to understanding the material. If you're actually interested in math, I recommend.

Homeworks had a definitive purpose and were awesome at helping you understand the material, where you explored things that we went over in lecture in much more detail. His lectures could be a bit slow, but that's because he always pauses to guarantee everyone understands. Office Hours are incredibly helpful, he goes through problems step by step

Sean can get a little distracted or side-tracked, but his lectures are interesting and thought-provoking. Highly recommend taking this class with him. He has taught it for many semesters and can guide you to an answer without telling you outright.

Lectures are almost purely theoretical. Homework did not match book did not match lecture. Would not fully answer questions in office hours. Part way through class started quizzes based on what he taught only two days before without office hours in between, even grad students at mathlab couldn't help.

Sean was the worst professor I've had for a math class at UW-Madison. His lectures were unorganized and unclear, and I can honestly say I didn't learn very much in this class. He was rude and didn't answer questions clearly, and we hardly covered the topics I was I expecting to learn for the course.

Sean was wonderful. He is amazingly knowledgeable and insightfully answered every question thrown at him. Lectures were clear and exams were fair. If you are actually interested in math he's great (but apparently if you are taking math 320 or 340 and want an easy A he is not your guy). Note that all of his reviews for 400+ courses are positive.

Just a terrible professor. I did really well in the class but I didn't learn a thing, his tests were mostly memorized proofs and he didn't even get into eigenvectors or values.  He has put me way behind for my future Math classes.  Avoid at all costs.

Sean was easily the worst professor I've had at UW Madison. He is unorganized, doesn't prepare for lectures, and refuses to answer questions in a direct, helpful manner. He is rude and I feel like I know less about math after taking his class. In a class that was half DiffEq and half linear algebra, we didn't even get to Eigen vectors. He's useless

Just a bad class to take. He spent way too much time on extremely abstract ideas, and never really followed the text book. Learned basically everything from youtube or from the the TA. There were zero examples done in the class, and he constantly spent tons of time just going over random theory. Avoid this guy

As a Math Major & possible Engineering student, I was surprised at how little I learned in this class. Lectures were disorganized and incoherent, his tests were unjustly written & graded. His focus on proofs made absolutely no sense for a such a low level Math/Engineering class. Do not take this class with Rostami. I will add that he's a nice guy.

Worst professor I have ever had, and that's saying a lot. To start, the lectures and the book are pretty much useless, he will post the ten page proofs that you need to memorize and discussion will cover everything you actually have to learn. I did the final with stuff I learned in dynamics and calc. AVOID AT ALL COSTS, TAKE THE FOREIGN PROFESSOR!!

Avoid this professor at all costs. All useful information taught could have been learned in two weeks of lecture but he spent a whole semester talking in a circle about the same things. Barely learned anything from his course and it killed my GPA. Terrible professor, is not encouraging or helpful at all. Kind of a rude person overall as well.
He is a terrible prof, he expects everyone to know some of the important math concepts coming into this class. He is harsh at grading. He does not explain the material well al all.
Terrible class. He is unorganized and doesn't explain things well. He also won't curve the class even when the average is a low C.
Half of the scores on the final exam were about materials he went over on the last lecture. Average is low and no curve.
No curve, no textbook use, be prepared to attend all lectures or you will be very behind. Tests are 50% memorization of theories. Avoid taking the class with him.

Horrendous. Poor at explaining topics and communicating expectations. Taught us extensive theory, and we hardly learned any actual math. After this class I still do not know what an eigen vector (essential concept in linear algebra) is, because he didn't teach it--only what he thought was important. Avoid at all costs.

Do not make the mistake I did. Avoid Rostami at all costs, if you want to keep your GPA up. One of many horrible professors at the UW math department. Too much focus on proofs, not enough focus on actual applications. He never uses the book, and as such we are required to learn completely in lecture. Avoid!!!!

Sean is by far the worst Math professor in the World. His grading sucks - no curve for any exams and all he talks about is proofs. He does not use the textbook - instead he pulls proofs out of thin air (not in the textbook) and then expects you to know it for the exam. Average grade will be a low C at best for this class. AVOID. AVOID. AVOID.

I've never felt inclined to write a review about a professor but Sean is such a horrible one I felt inclined. This is supposed to be a computation based course that he teaches based off of 100% proofs and theorems. The exams are difficult and NOT CURVED. So far the averages have been about 70%. AVOID HIM AT ALL COSTS

Sean was the wrong professor for this class. He may be well suited for higher level math classes where theorems and proofs are more relevant. 320 is a computational class. Quoted "Is it somewhat unfair to people who took the class this time instead of last year? Yes." Referring to him not curving the class and having a class average around a 71%

As an engineering student, I wouldn't have taken this course if I knew it would be proof based with very minimal computation. Sean is frustrating as a professor and gives no partial credit. This is the first Math class I've taken that will not be curved and I can honestly say I am very worried about my GPA. Please Avoid.

AVOID THIS PROFESSOR AT ALL COSTS. As other reviews say, he focuses mainly on concepts and theory rather than teaching you/giving examples of how to solve things. His grading scale is also HORRIBLE. No curve on an exam worth 25% of grade, average was a 64%.

Horrible grading system. No curve at all for such a difficult class and the class average is C. He tests proofs and recitation of theorems. Far more difficult than it should be. Not a math major and really regret taking it with him.
Not recommended if you are not math major. He focuses on CONCEPTS A LOT! Definitions and description of theorems will be tested on the exams! No curve! Not recommended!
not a good class to take. However, comments about the professor being rude are untrue, the reviewers are just a bunch of softies

DO NOT TAKE AT ALL COSTS. Wait a semester if you have to, retrospectively I should have. He is rude and unhelpful. His exams are so harshly graded and his curve is horrible. All the other teachers have far easier classes. I am doing somewhat well in this class comparatively and I will likely get a C. I never write reviews but this is different.

Rostami is very unorganized. He doesn't seem to prepare a lot for lecture, and his thought processes are all over the place. At the end of a unit, you have to sit down and map everything out to see how it fits together. When you ask questions, his answers are unrelated. He's also been very rude in emails/discussion posts on Learn@UW. Try to avoid.

It's not the end of the world to take the Math 320 with him but avoid it if possible. Smart guy, bad personality. He's disrespectful when he addresses emails and questions in class. Did better on the exams with material I taught myself. Out of 5 semesters of math and science courses, I've never had such a poor experience with a prof at UW.

Avoid at all costs! This class was entirely proof/fact/theorem based taught entirely with words. Very arrogant personality and shows little interest in making his teaching student friendly. Exams are crazy hard and worth 90% of the grade. Homework was graded like a joke, and did not help to gauge how well you knew the material.

You can hardly find a professor who is more theory-focused than the textbook is..but Sean is one. He has a wrong understanding in the purpose of this class. His lectures, homeworks, exams are filled with proofs and theories, despite the fact that the majority of the class are engineering students who are supposed to use math for practical purposes.

Sean is a very smart dude. The lectures are very fast, rather incoherent but always well-presented. That said, everything written on the board is either a proof,theorem, definition,exception,fact, statement, etc. THERE ARE ZERO computational examples done in class. This class caters to very advanced students.  I Disliked it enough to write a review

Sean is the worst professor I have ever had. He is teaching a non-proof based class with proofs. It is difficult to understand where he is going with his lectures. Besides his bad teaching system, he swears in lecture and uses offensive language. He assumed his students were 3rd year engineering students when we were all 1st or 2nd year students.

At all costs do not take this professor! Requires advanced graphing calculators for exams, but tells you in the beginning of the class graphing calculators are not required. Tests are primarily proof based, which is not what Math 320 is supposed to be. He says he makes exams difficult to "separate the talent." AWFUL PROFESSOR DO NOT TAKE!!!!
He is a proof based teacher in a non-proof based class. He jumps around and barely uses the textbook. Math 320 should not be as tough of a class as he makes it. Avoid Sean at all costs

Sean is a horrible professor. His lectures are extremely boring and disorganized. The homeworks are based off of lecture and the textbook. Questions not from the book are very unclear and difficult to solve. Exam scores are pretty much the whole grade for the class which he does not curve. I would avoid taking this class with Sean if  possible.

Sean can be difficult to follow at times in lecture but he seriously cares about your education. I've spent a decent amount of time in office hours with him and I have been really successful. He's a really good guy but this is can be tough course if you don't try. You get out of it what you put in. Plane and simple.

Lectures were difficult to understand, though the homework often brought clarity. Fast-paced and difficult, but not *too* difficult. I think that the overall course structure was pretty good. I learned a ton. I'm a little disappointed that I didn't get an A, though. I did very poorly on 1 exam, and the grading scheme made it difficult to recover.

Prior to this class,I was interested in Intro to Linear Algebra. But it has been semester of struggling with proofs, and trying to absorb all of the material from lecture. A nice person and willing to help, but chose a wrong approach.

AVOID THIS PROFESSOR! He did not teach the course that was advertised. We focused on proofs instead of computations even though the class is intended for physicists and engineers. This was definitely not the "intro" class I was expecting. Really, avoid this professor at all costs!

Like others are saying, he is a very nice guy. But, he made this course much more difficult than it should have been. Lectures disorganized, a few times he rushed thru VERY important concept with 5-10 minutes of class left and then assigned those concepts as homework. His grading scale (released a week ago) does not fit the course difficulty well.

Sean is enthusiastic, but his method of teaching is wrong. Begins by kindly answering questions, but then he progresses into difficult concepts before completely clarifying rudimentary topics. Quote: "[the final exam] numbers are tame." The first problem didn't have anything close to tame numbers... He is a nice person, but not the best teacher. :/

Very enthusiastic and easy to get along with. Always open to talk about things. Provides great notes in lecture, although he does tend to get a little sidetracked. I am actually putting off taking classes so that I can take them with him. If you show up for lecture and show him that you're trying, you're almost sure to get a decent grade

Dreading this final. Sean is a nice guy, and I don't mind hard work, but he is not teaching the advertised course. All proofs and 1 month from now, all will be forgotten. He's made this course conceptually more difficult than 3rd semester calc course. theory/proofs fine to learn, but exams for this class SHOULD NOT BE 80% PROOFS!

Avoid him, if you can. I came into this class expecting to learn, without having to struggle to pass. This is an ELEMENTARY course, Sean. He taught too much abstract ideas, and did not introduce topics well. He just dove into them. Also, why was majority of homework and exams proofs? Again, this is an elementary course, Sean. I learned 90% from TA.

This was treated as math 341 and then some. Zero computations in class, complex computations on the exams, 90% of the homework was proofs, no review sessions, zero practice exams. His intentions are off, he needs to connect with the students better and understand that majority of people learn better by seeing examples.

Sean's approach is all wrong.  This is an applied course; not a theory course such as 341. There can be proofs, but not at the level of abstraction that he provides.He lost everyone! Compare the syllabus to other linalg courses.No applications covered: no prin components,page rank,svd, fourier series,etc. endless proofs instead! A lost oppty.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Lecture makes no sense, he skips basic concepts and goes straight into high level stuff without explaining the concepts at all. Way too many proofs. Homework is poorly written and extremely long.

Lecture and notes are worse than useless. Any time I try to learn from them, I come away more confused. Makes up questions for homework that are proof heavy and usually unclear. I agree with other raters: he teaches like this is MA341. Avoid at all costs.

Lectures are hard to follow. Provides lecture notes, but even harder to follow. Homework is mostly proofs and poorly written problems. Exams were either proofs or very tedious problems. Obviously loves the subject, but is probably the worst Math prof I've had. Even worse than Calc 1 and 2 profs, which is saying something.

Avoid him!! His lectures are disorganized and incoherent.  He seemed to hate using numerical examples that would help the class, and rather enjoyed proof-based examples.  Oh, and he had a penchant for saying that something was "obvious" and refusing to elaborate further when questions were asked.  His expectations of us were way beyond Math 340.

His level of mathematical thinking and student expectation is well above what is expected for an introductory linear algebra course. He has embedded proofs into every homework and exam, his examples are done using symbols and letters when a numerical example would be much more effective. I would stay away if you are taking 340.

His first time teaching math 340. Very Nice Guy and wanted to help, but did not help. He would not help us through the homework problems before they were due, even if we showed up at his office, at the cost of us not learning the material. Made his class entirely proof based, which is what 341 is supposed to be!
Very helpful! He is modest and patient when student have questions. Very intellengent in math!

Sean is really nice and would like to help everyone. He is very fair when I found grading issues and argue with him, he gave me credits back when he felt necessary. Very reasonable and very great lectures!
Very nice guy, extremely helpful. He is able to clearly get across the tough ideas. He made the analysis course very enjoyable.
even though the material is very tough, professor Sean is very willing to help.
Sean was super helpful. The class ends up being quite easy as long as you try and laugh at his jokes in class. Interested in helping people learn. Don't need to be the most clever person to get an A.

Great professor, he actually wants to help you learn. Whenever I was confused I would email him for help and he would really take the time to explain things to me. Also, he really encouraged questions in class. My only suggestion is, if you're taking 541, buy the book "A book of abstract algebra" by Pinter. The book we used was pretty awful.
He's a good guy who really seems to want to help. If you have questions or are confused, read the book and then go ask him for help and he'll usually do everything he can to help.
